title: Royal Mail Bosses to Explain Letter Delivery Problems to Parliament
summary: Royal Mail bosses will go to Parliament to talk about problems with delivering letters. The BBC found out that many people are upset because their letters arrive late. Some people missed hospital appointments or did not get important papers like school certificates. Postal workers say they are too busy and sometimes focus more on parcels than letters. A group in Parliament called the Business and Trade Committee asked Royal Mail to explain these issues. Royal Mail says it wants to talk about how it is changing to fix the problems. The company was bought by a billionaire last year, and he promised to care for workers and customers. But now, even first-class mail is often late. Royal Mail blames bad weather and sick workers for some delays, but many people are still unhappy.

background_read: Royal Mail is the main postal service in the UK, responsible for delivering letters and parcels to homes and businesses. Parliament is where elected officials, called MPs, work to make laws and oversee companies like Royal Mail. A committee is a small group of MPs that investigates specific issues, such as mail delivery problems. When mail is late, it can cause serious issues, like missing important appointments or documents. This article explains how Royal Mail is being asked to fix these problems.
Article_Structure: WHO: Royal Mail bosses and the Business and Trade Committee in Parliament
WHAT: Problems with delivering letters on time, causing people to miss important things
WHERE: In the UK, especially in Parliament and delivery offices
WHY: Because postal workers are too busy and prioritize parcels, and Royal Mail needs to explain how to improve
